billsco

The last time an ivory-billed woodpecker had been seen was in 1944, according to this site, and was officially listed as extinct. A positive sighting has been reported, according to the journal Science. 
 
 This has sent shockwaves and cries of joy throughout birdom. I must admit I got caught up in all the fuss when I heard about it yesterday on NPR.  Here's a more detailed story of the sighting. NPR has a link on their site also, but I haven't visited it. They planned on doing more on the story today.
 
 But is it that big of a deal? It sounds as though just one mating pair requires huges tracts of undisturbed forest to succeed. They certainly will never be plentiful. 
 
 I dunno. Still it is exciting in some way.
zelma
I read about that too, I wonder how they were missed for so long.
Diogenes99

A rancher in southern Arizona shot a striped tiger (looks quite a bit like a Bengal tiger) a few years ago. Once native to the area, the tiger had been thought to be extinct since 1910.
 
 The black-footed ferret was once feared to be extinct, but a rancher near Meteetse, WY, found a colony of them. The Fish & Wildlife Service rounded all of them up - every single one - and took them into captivity to protect them. They promptly caught distemper and they all died. So the F&WS troops went back to the ranch and got some more.
 
 The common moral to all of these stories is that our biologists do a poor job of counting and/or estimating populations, and concerns about "endangered" species are invariably overrated.
Duo_Maxwell

Yet that hardly invalidades the very premise of relying upon scientists to give factual information. Merely because they screwed up a few times doesn't mean that we can disregard all of their findings.
Diogenes99

Yet that hardly invalidades the very premise of relying upon scientists to give factual information. Merely because they screwed up a few times doesn't mean that we can disregard all of their findings.
For those who hang onto their beliefs in face of near-uniformly contradictory facts, you are probably right. The rest of us will assign their "scientific" conclusions a probability of being right, based on their track record.
 
 Happiness is a warm planet.
Spad

 This has sent shockwaves and cries of joy throughout birdom. I must admit I got caught up in all the fuss when I heard about it yesterday on NPR.  Here's a more detailed story of the sighting. NPR has a link on their site also, but I haven't visited it. They planned on doing more on the story today.
 
 But is it that big of a deal? It sounds as though just one mating pair requires huges tracts of undisturbed forest to succeed. They certainly will never be plentiful.

 Smithsonian Magazine also has a decent article on it:
 
 http://www.smithsonianmag.si.edu/smithsonian/issues05/aug05/presence.html
Dono

Sure, there are some that claim that the GTSAA (Great Texas Spotted XXX Ape) is extinct. Since they are the world's fastest animal, too fast to be detected by the human eye, some (Yankees) have even questioned their existence. Some in Texas, myself included, still use the old expression, "faster than a Spotted XXX Ape" to describe something that is REALLY fast. I have often felt that little whiff of cool air as a single GTSAA passed by, and a phenomenon called a twister or tornado can occur during mating season when they are running at full speed. I have been trying to bag a trophy GTSAA (male with at least 32 spots) for over 40 years. Believe me, it gets lonely sitting in a folding chair, drinking beer and holding out that net.
 I would tell you more, but the guard is here with my medication.
 Dono
georged

 When I do that for any extended period of time my wife makes unkind remarks regarding motivation, liver and selfishness. Dono, you're a genius. I'm headed out to buy some nets. And a net holder.
